definition: fire/urgent/ammunition/fiery or flaming/internal heat (Chinese medicine)/hot (popular)/classifier for military units (old)/Kangxi radical 86
thread/string/wire/line/CL:條|条[tiao2],股[gu3],根[gen1]/(after a number) tier (unofficial ranking of a Chinese city)
fuse (for explosives)/(fig.) proximate cause/the last straw
fuse (for explosives)/(fig.) proximate cause/the last straw

sentences.english: Forever fire resistance is made from aramid materials, with high cost on production.
sentences.chinese: 永久性防火線爲芳綸材料製成，成本較高。

sentences.english: The two trends of overthrowing Sun Yat-sen were merely a fuse of reorganization Restoration League.
sentences.chinese: 二次“倒孫風潮”不過是光復會重組的導火線而已。

sentences.english: Parking in the fire lane will lead to fine.
sentences.chinese: 在防火線內停車是要受罰的。

sentences.english: The immediate orchard boundary should consist of a fire-break.
sentences.chinese: 緊靠種子園邊界應設有防火線。

sentences.english: They could see the smoke of the burning lint-stock.
sentences.chinese: 人們看到點燃了的引火線在冒煙。

sentences.english: When playing across the line of fire marksmanship training from the beginning of what?
sentences.chinese: 在玩穿越火線時練槍法是從什麼開始？

sentences.english: Although he was seriously wounded, he flatly refused to quit the battle line.
sentences.chinese: 他雖然身負重傷，但堅決不下火線。

sentences.english: Do not cross the line - of -fire of friendly units whenever possible.
sentences.chinese: 儘可能在任何時候都不要穿越自己人的火線。

sentences.english: At that point, the fuse ignites the bursting charge, which explodes the shell.
sentences.chinese: 這時候，導火線引然爆炸點，然後就會有煙火。

sentences.english: A wild fire jump contained line in California came out with a half mile upon ranches.
sentences.chinese: 野外大火在加州大牧場形成半里火線。

definition: to return to one's unit/to go back to one's station in life
to ride to take up an official appointment (idiom); to take on a job with alacrity/to undertake a task
(in classical literature) young military officer of high rank for his age/(during the Cultural Revolution) young militant in the Red Guard/(in modern usage) rising star (in sport, politics etc)
treasure knife does not age (idiom); old but still vigorous
to heal a wound/to recuperate (from an injury)
to mess sth up/to screw up
